name: Molecular Cloud
description: Molecular cloud: The root of the tree are often referred to as “stellar nurseries” because they are the birthplace of stars. These interstellar clouds consist of a mix of gas, dust, and plasma. Regions of molecular clouds that collapse under the force of gravity begin to produce any number of stellar objects from tiny planets to giant stars.

children.name: Open Cluster
children.description: Open cluster: The gravitational collapse of gas and dust pushes the stars to the next stage in a star’s lifetime, which occurs in an open cluster. An open cluster is a star cluster composed of tens of thousands of stars. These stars form from the same molecular cloud and are roughly the same age. The stars here are protostars, very young stars that are still accumulating mass from the molecular cloud. Pictured here is one of the most famous open clusters: the Pleiades Cluster, also known as the seven sisters.

children.name: Massive Star
children.description: Massive star: Stars of >8 solar masses - that’s eight times more than our Sun. They are typically some of the brightest stars in the night sky. It takes a lot of energy for massive stars to burn, so they live very fast and die hard.

children.name: Red Supergiant
children.description: Red supergiant: Red supergiant stars are massive stars that are approaching the later years of their lives. They are hundreds to thousands of times larger than the Sun and their red color is indicative of cooler temperatures. These stars burn heavier elements until they develop an iron core, which results in a supernova explosion.

children.name: Type II Supernova
children.description: Type II supernova: When stars with approximately 8-50 solar masses die, a rapid collapse and violent explosion occurs. This explosion is known as a supernova. Type II supernovae are distinguished from other supernovae by their hydrogen abundance.

children.name: Supernova remnant
children.description: Supernova remnants: These are the structures left over from explosions of stars that result in supernovae. They consist of ejected material expanding from the force of the explosion, and are key components to understanding the ecology of galaxies.

children.name: Black Hole
children.description: Black hole: A region in space that is so dense that the gravitational pull becomes too strong for anything to escape - not even light.

children.name: Neutron Star
children.description: Neutron star: Collapsed cores from supergiant stars. Aside from black holes, they are the densest known objects in our Universe. But unlike a black hole, they do not have the mass necessary to trap light. Once a star collapses into a neutron star it no longer generates heat and begins to cool over time. Neutron stars typically have a radius of about 10 kilometers and mass of ~1.4 solar masses.

children.name: Low-Mass Star
children.description: Low mass stars: Stars of <8 solar masses spend most of their life fusing hydrogen and helium in their core, which causes them to be the longest lived energy-producing objects in the Universe. Low mass stars are the most abundant, most difficult to detect, and can live for trillions of years.

children.name: Red Giant
children.description: Red giant: These giants are stars that have run out of hydrogen fuel for nuclear fusion and begun the process of dying. Thir atmosphere is inflated making their apparent radius large but thir temperature low.

children.name: Binary White Dwarf
children.description: White dwarf binary stars: extreme systems that radiate gravitational waves as they orbit each other. To balance the loss of this energy, the stars gradually come closer together until eventually they merge. Many white dwarf binaries will explode as supernovae when they merge, but this newly discovered one is too small to trigger such an explosion. Instead, it will probably start fusing its helium atoms, and when it does - in about 37 million years - it will shine like a normal star again.

children.name: Type 1a Supernova
children.description: Type 1a Supernova: Stars >1.4 solar masses can create a Type Ia Supernova. These occur in binary systems (two stars orbiting one another) in which one of the stars is a white dwarf. The other star can be anything from a giant star to an even smaller white dwarf.

children.name: Nova
children.description: Nova: Stars <1.4 solar masses can create a nova. This is an explosion from the surface of a white-dwarf star in a binary star system. A nova occurs when the white dwarf, which is the dense core of a once-normal star, steals gas from its nearby companion star. When enough gas builds up on the surface of the white dwarf it triggers an explosion.

children.name: Planetary Nebula
children.description: Planetary Nebula: A type of emission nebula consisting of an expanding, glowing shell of ionized gas ejected from red giant stars late in their lives. The term 'planetary nebula' is a misnomer because they are unrelated to planets. All planetary nebulae form at the end of the life of a star of intermediate mass, about 1-8 solar masses. It is expected that the Sun will form a planetary nebula at the end of its life cycle. They are relatively short-lived phenomena, lasting perhaps a few tens of millennia, compared to considerably longer phases of stellar evolution.

children.name: white Dwarf
children.description: White dwarf: what stars like the Sun become after they have exhausted their nuclear fuel. Near the end of its nuclear burning stage, this type of star expels most of its outer material, creating a planetary nebula. Only the hot core of the star remains.

children.name: Brown Dwarf
children.description: Brown dwarf: Stars of <0.08 solar masses (also called failed stars) are substellar objects that, while more massive than the most massive gas giant planets, are not massive enough to sustain nuclear fusion of ordinary hydrogen into helium in their cores.
